video.title: Solidity Tutorial - A Full Course on Ethereum, Blockchain Development, Smart Contracts, and the EVM
video.description:
Learn to program in Solidity in the full tutorial. Solidity is an object-oriented programming language for writing smart contracts. It is used for implementing smart contracts on various blockchain platforms, most notably, Ethereum.

🔗 Solidity article with code: http://www.dappuniversity.com/articles/solidity-tutorial

🎥 Course created by Dapp University. Check out their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/dappuniversity
🔗 Dapp University Free Blockchain Developer Training: http://www.dappuniversity.com/bootcamp

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (12:03) Part 2
⌨️ (32:34) Part 3
⌨️ (46:32) Part 4
⌨️ (1:00:48) Part 5
⌨️ (1:18:35) Part 6

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Alfred Peter
topLevelComment.text:
In part 4 at 51:25, why is the wallet set inside the constructor? I tried compiling the contract after omitting the constructor block and it worked just fine without any errors. 
For the sake of clarity, I haven't gone beyond that point in the tutorial, so at the time I'm writing this, I don't know if it'll become useful down the line. But as things are, the address constructor *seems* unnecessary even though I know it wouldn't be there if it wasn't important.

replies.author: Alfred Peter
replies.text: Update: I just realized that the address constructor forces the person calling the contract to provide their address before -deploying- calling it. I considered deleting my question but I figured I'd leave it up here in case someone else in the future will be asking the same thing.

Unlikely that it would work right. It'd be like trying to host the gmail web client software from your own server. Maybe doable, but certainly tricky.

replies.author: Marc Herzog
replies.text: Don't day trade. Keep to weekly/daily timeframes, observe the trend (the trend is your friend) and don't shoot in all directions. Technical analysis is nothing more than the study of emotions. Don't use a million indicators. Patience is key and remember, it's just a question of probabilities.

replies.author: Roch Brz
replies.text:
Yeah, one advice and very simple.

DON'T TRADE.

1. Research where Ethereum is going
2. Find ecosystem critical projects. So something that is necessary for the long term success of Web3, solid use case.  e.g. Chainlink or Graph
3. Invest in these tokens and hodl.
4. (BONUS) get involved into communities of these projects, learn and maybe even try to build something.
5. Relax and focus on something else, like your real job, family and friends, a hobby.
6. Don't check your portfolio all the time
7. Check your portfolio in 2-5 years
8. Buy a Lambo.

Good luck mate.

replies.author: Kozie
replies.text:
@J knowledgenet Stuff like Crypto Kitties are tokens (smart contracts) on the Ethereum Blockchain. Since they're on the blockchain no one can take them away from you unless the blockchain gets successfully attacked, that's the main reason people want to deploy certain applications or tokens on the blockchain instead of a centralized server. Smart contracts are basically programs that run on the blockchain. They don't need to include any tokens. They can't be manipulated and their code is 100% transparent.  

So basically a smart contract itself doesn't have any value, it's just code that is being executed on the blockchain instead of a centralized server. There are endless use-cases for smart contracts.

replies.author: XDTuber
replies.text: no one is able to change the code,  only you as the coder who created the code can change the code, but with public setters, user accounts on this blockchain will be able to change values of variables stored on the blockchain.

replies.author: XDTuber
replies.text:
that means if you have an account for this deployed blockchain, then you can see the values of public variables (with a public getter function or just set the variable as public) and set values with public setter functions, and if it is internal it is not exposed on the public interface (what you see on the right hand side where you have the public variable and function buttons. 


 If you want some functions that you don't want a user to use, e.g., a function that displays a string with all firstnames of users separated by commas, then you can make an internal helper function.  Maybe you want to have a few public functions that need to use a string of all firstnames, so instead of typing the code to get this each time, you can just call your internal helper function.  But the user won't be able to directly call this function; it is only callable within the code.


public = callable from outside of code (accessible to users)
internal = only callable from inside of code (not accessible to users)

topLevelComment.text: What prerequisites are needed (or assumptions expected about the person watching) to be able to fully follow along with this tutorial?

replies.author: Omar Awad
replies.text: Since Solidity is very Class-centric and focuses alot on OOP, learn the basics of Java. No need to master Java,just learn the basics since it is a statically-typed language, just like Solidity. You can also learn JavaScript as well since Solidity's syntax is similar to it.

replies.author: Empress Sandra
replies.text: @densch123 you don't need that much of indepth knowledge about blockchain to follow this tutorial. You should know that blockchain is used to store data, and that you can manipulate data with a smart contract. It's like programming in any language: yes it could be helpful to know assembly and memory management but do you need any of that stuff to write hello world oh hello no

replies.author: Empress Sandra
